awd_titl_txt: Size-Selective Electrochemical Sensing via Metal-Organic Supercontainers
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Electrochemical sensing of ions has a critical role in various fields including clinical analysis, environmental monitoring, and industrial process control. One particularly important subgroup of electrochemical sensors are ion-selective electrodes (ISEs), which detect target ions by electrical signals. Although a variety of organic molecules have been used in ISEs as ion-carriers (known as "ionophores") to improve the selectivity in ion sensing, the scope of applications for these ionophore-based ISEs remains restricted due to the chemical limitations of the organic ionophores. The project led by Dr. Zhenqiang Wang at the University of South Dakota and Dr. Nathan Netzer at Peru State College addresses this challenge by integrating into the ISEs a family of complex host molecules as a new class of ionophores. These hosts exhibit highly unique and tunable chemical structures, making it feasible to achieve size-selective and predetermined ion sensing. This new approach not only significantly expands the scope of ISEs, but has the potential to transform the design of ionophore-based ISEs. This project contains a strong educational and outreach component that aims to promote science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education among two specific groups of underrepresented student populations, namely, tribal college students and students from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs). Undergraduates at Peru State College, a small rural PUI in Peru, Nebraska, are part of the team to perform cutting-edge research in the field of electrochemical sensing.  The team also plans to conduct chemistry workshops at regional tribal colleges and host tribal student-faculty pairs to perform summer research at the University of South Dakota.

Technical Abstract:
Designing new ionophores in ISEs for the specific task of molecular ion sensing continues to present significant challenges. The new class of ionophores utilized in this project represents a unique family of synthetic receptors known as metal-organic supercontainers (MOSCs). The favorable chemical and structural characteristics of the MOSCs, including their compositional versatility, structural modularity, and multi-pore architecture distinguish them from other synthetic ionophores and provide unprecedented opportunities for functionalizing ISEs and engineering new electrochemical sensing applications. This two-year project focuses on three specific aims: 1) incorporation of MOSCs into various polymeric mixed-matrix membranes; 2) fundamental studies of MOSC integrated ISEs; 3) tuning the specificity of ISEs by incorporating target-specific MOSCs. By participating in this research activity, graduate students, and undergraduate researchers are exposed to a diverse set of experimental techniques ranging from materials synthesis and electrochemical analysis to device fabrication.

por.por_cntn:
Molecular recognition and sensing of various chemical species is an indispensable part of our technology-driven society today. Modular sensors that possess the ability for miniaturization, improved selectivity, and application-based tunability have become the hallmark of current state-of-the-art research in sensor fabrication. Over the past decades, ion-selective electrodes (ISEs), an important type of electrochemical sensors, have gained an important role in many areas such as environmental monitoring and clinical diagnostics due to their simplicity, portability, and low cost. Among the various components in a typical ISE, molecules serving as ?ionophores? are of particular importance, as they are directly responsible for selectively targeting ions of interest and generating detectable electrochemical signals. Although in recent decades tremendous progress has been made in the field, use of ISEs is largely limited to the sensing of small inorganic ions (e.g., Na+, K+, Cl-, etc.) due to a lack of selective ionophores suitable for recognizing larger organic and molecular ions, many of which are of environmental or diagnostic significance.

The central goal of this project was to develop and study a new class of ionophores suitable for recognizing and sensing larger organic/molecular ions that are of environmental and biological relevance. Our approach focused on utilizing a family of synthetic receptor molecules known as metal-organic supercontainers (MOSCs), which represent a group of novel ?host? molecules featuring multiple nano-cavities. MOSCs are highly modular structures that can be tuned by adjusting metal ions, carboxylate linkers, and container precursors known as sulfonylcalix[4]arenes. The most significant attribute of the MOSC structures was that the size, shape, and chemical environment of their nano-cavities can be chemically modified to specifically target molecular ions of interest.

We demonstrated that MOSCs were indeed suitable as ionophores, as they can be readily incorporated into polymer membranes and fabricated into ISE sensing devices. Working with a team of collaborators in Sweden, we constructed a MOSC-incorporated ISE prototype and tested water samples containing both methylene blue, a common dye and large organic cation, and K+. We found that the MOSC-based sensor can selectively detect methylene blue over K+ in the ?M concentration range, thus validating the proof of concept. We also expanded the scope of the work beyond cation sensing and designed a number of MOSCs that were promising for recognizing and sensing anions, which is arguably technologically more challenging but practically more important than cation sensing.

We further illustrated the integration of MOSC-based ionophores with silicon nanowire ion-sensitive field-effect transistors (SiNWFET) and the fabrication of chip sensor arrays. This allowed multiplexed analysis of both molecular and elemental ions in a single analyte. For example, using a SiNWFET sensor array incorporated with a commercial ionophore and a MOSC-based ionophore, detection of two distinct cations, namely, Na+ and methylene blue, was achieved in a multiplexed manner with controlled sensitivities. The potential interference of the hydrophobic methylene blue ion to the detection of Na+ was mitigated by modifying the ISE with a hydrophilic polyethylene glycol composition.

This project also contained a strong educational outreach component. The PI worked and collaborated closely with students and faculty from Peru State College (PSC), a local primarily undergraduate institution (PUI) in rural Nebraska. Dr. Nate Netzer, a tenure-track assistant professor at PSC, was the co-PI on this grant and played a key role in MOSC sensor fabrication and testing. As a subawardee, Dr. Netzer received a significant portion of the funding support, which allowed him to maintain an active research program, advising and supporting at least five PSC students to participate in undergraduate research. Dr. Netzer was also instrumental in helping recruit a total of three PSC students to participate in summer research in the PI?s laboratory. Upon completing the summer research program, these students returned to PSC and brought the expertise they learned in the PI?s group with them, enabling them to continue working on related research in Dr. Netzer?s laboratory during the academic year. This outreach partnership thus provided an effective approach to engaging PUI faculty and students in intensive research activities.
